title: Invisible Landscapes

author: Gonzalo Herrero Delicado, Royal Academy of Arts

segmentation: I'd like to start with the like video.
It's only like 2 minutes, but it's quite clear to explain what we are, where we are heading to.
In 1768, a group of artists and architects came together to form the Royal Academy of Arts.
They were driven to create an independent institution that would be run by artists who would be elected by their peers.
The Academy would provide a venue for exhibitions and lectures open to the public and establish an art school through which their skills and knowledge could be passed on to future generations.
For almost 250 years, these artists known as Royal Academicians have been shaping the countries understanding, appreciation and creation of visual art.
the Royal Academy remains an independent and privately funded charity.
It continues to host world class exhibitions and debates and to provide free art education for a new generation of artists.
And it's still run by the country's greatest living artists and architects.
Those are 250th birthday approaches.
We're embarking on a major transformation.
Our buildings on Piccadilly and Burlington Gardens will be united through designs by internationally acclaimed architect, said David Chipperfield RA.
New public galleries and displays will reveal treasures from a historic collection and provide a showcase for works by students and today's leading artists.
A-250 seat, auditorium and a purpose built Learning Center will enable many more people to take part in learning and debates about visual culture.
Our new facilities will enable us to provide a better welcome for our friends and visitors.
Our plans will open up the Royal Academy as never before creating a revitalized destination for artists and the public in the very heart of London.
All in time for our 250th birthday in 2018.
